channel.title: C++ io
channel.description:
I got a problem encountered recently and need someone to enlighten me on it.
I read words in a file and store them in a char** array and I can display them on the console as I read them, but I can't display them after the file reading is finished.
Like if I try
[code] cout << words[24] << endl; system("pause"); [/code]
It display nothing.

item.title: C++ io
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

The Enforcer:

It’s good that you solved the problem yourself and that you use the superior C++ language.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ io
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

I can’t use strings, I’m limited to chars. I found the error, it was an adress problem, but I solved my problem.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ io
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

first of all replace that system(“pause”) with something like cin.get()

now ask yourself why you’re using a char** in C++ srsly… what appears to be your required functionality could be accomplished with a std::liststd::string& or something along those idiomatic lines

Read full topic

item.title: C++ io
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

I even tried it before the ifstream.close(), but it won’t display, only while it reads them.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ io
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Something tells me because it’s a char** array, it’s full of pointers to the file stream, which you’re then closing.

Read full topic

@Hash1 wrote:

I got a problem encountered recently and need someone to enlighten me on it.

I read words in a file and store them in a char** array and I can display them on the console as I read them, but I can’t display them after the file reading is finished.

Like if I try

cout << words[24] << endl;
system("pause");
